results.title: The Best Remaining Seats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
John Baxter, well known Australian historian and cinema critic, examines the fall of the great cinema houses, how the Hollywood industry built them and Hollywood acted as a magnet for both talent and money. Charlie Chaplin’s career is also analysed. This episode is one of the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Switzerland/Texas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filming in Australia has been described as “Switzerland wanting to go to Texas”. In this program, John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the state of the Australian film industry. This is part five of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck” which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Ballad of a soldier = Ballada o soldate
results.creator_credit: Grigori Chukhrai, M Chernova and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Amid the chaos of WW2, a young Russian soldier earns a pass home, for an act of heroism. En route he is detained constantly, as he helps others on their way, managing only the briefest of encounters with his forlorn mother, before returning to active duty. This acclaimed drama speaks of the hardship of war as experienced by the Russian people and of the sadness of separation. It also depicts the sensuality of youth, a theme previously denied Russian filmmakers, but allowed during the “thaw” as it was known, a period in the 1950s of Soviet cinema.

results.title: You Can't Say That
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Oh! The problems of censorship! John Baxter shows, from the days of seemingly innocuous material such as the Keystone Cops to the present, that there have been recurrent problems with Censorship boards. This program, part of a ten part documentary, Filmstruck, considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Destiny of a man = Sudba cheloveka
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Melancholy and sympathetic view of the tragedies suffered by a family man and WW2 POW survivor. Haunted by his experiences in a concentration camp the man has survived this appalling event by clinging to the hope of reuniting with his wife and child. Directed by, and also starring Sergei Bondarchuk, this was a successful film that with its unstinting humanism, proved the ability of Russian filmmakers to combine cinematic beauty with compassionate sentiment.

results.title: The Blink of an eye
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
This is part two of “Filmstruck”, a series hosted by the well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, John Baxter, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience. In this episode, John Baxter takes a closer look at cinema stunts and the men that performed them, from early Tom Mix to Mad Max 2.

results.title: The Star = Zvezda
results.creator_credit: Nikolai Lebedev, Karen Shakhnazarov and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Based on the book by Emmanuil Kazakevich, this film focuses on a group of Russian scouts in WW2, aiming to penetrate Nazi communications and thwart a major attack. Echoing the themes of Steven Spielberg’s “Saving Private Ryan” (2000), director Nikolai Lebedev presents war as chaotic, taxing and disorienting. At times quite claustrophobic, the film works best when presenting the dangerously fraught reconnaissance missions undertaken by the unit.

results.title: Poor Man's Cinema
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
It’s what countries like Australia produce - documentaries! John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the renaissance of the ‘60s as well as the Hollywood wartime documentaries, and their effect on the evolution of cinema.

group_works.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
group_works.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
results.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Folktales from around the world”.
An animated story about a Chinese potter who makes a beautiful porcelain teapot for the Emperor who regards its worth as priceless. It is then seen to be desirable and is inevitably stolen from the Emperor’s palace. In a series of transactions that follow in various parts of the world, it is exchanged for items from other cultures that are equally regarded as priceless. Provides a simple introduction to the notion of trade, as well as the economic and aesthetic considerations involved in the determination of the worth of a product. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.
